hints.content:
Lets figure out the factors for the rows and columns. Then we can multiply to find the missing values.

![The same table as above, marked with a multiplication symbol.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/99f24fe0eeb1631c2351755680a7c466578f2c85)

$18 \stackrel{\maroonD{+3}}{\longrightarrow} 21 \stackrel{\maroonD{+3}}{\longrightarrow} 24$

The factor for the first row is $\maroonD{3}$.

![The same table as above, with the first row labeled 3.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/d16d422e141c4f2d9a12539ba08c7748920d1380)

The factor for each row of a multiplication table is one more than the row above it.

![The same table as above, with the rows labeled 3, 4, and 5 respectively.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/0cb5101f781088ede28f6acf233519097e8059ec)

$18 \stackrel{\blueE{+6}}{\longrightarrow} 24 \stackrel{\blueE{+6}}{\longrightarrow} 30$

The factor for the first column is $\blueE{6}$.

![The same table as above, with the first column labeled 6.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/b84da0acd90dd7296f7b01d8ab8cbc63879318e6)

The factor for each column of a multiplication table is one more than the column left of it.

![The same table as above, with the columns labeled 6, 7, and 8 respectively.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/9e8747e2e5030bf6ab2dbbad87e45f9f8ad692c1)

Now we know the factors, so we can multiply to find the missing numbers.

$4 \times 7 = 28$

![The same table as above, with intersection of row 4 and column 7 labeled 28.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/6a6985f58b2d4d521b1f093f4445de82e066e3b3)

$5 \times 7 = 35$

![The same table as above, with intersection of row 5 and column 7 labeled 35.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/ea38146ded6cbf6cf1bf90fcc0539f0319adcbb3)

Here is the completed pattern.

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A partial multiplication table with 3 rows and 3 columns. The first row reads 18, 21, 24. The second row reads 24, 28, 32. The third row reads 30, 35, 40. !

question.content:
Part of a multiplication table is below.

**Complete the pattern in the multiplication table.**

[[☃ label-image 1]]

options.imageAlt: A partial multiplication table with 3 rows and 3 columns. The first row reads 18, 21, 24. The second row reads 24, an unknown number, 32. The third row reads 30, an unknown number, 40.

markers.label: The unknown number in the second row and second column
The unknown number in the third row and second column
